blocks.value: Interior desing is basically a course that teaches students about the skills and knowledge that are required to create a beautiful and functional space . Interior Design mostly focuses on creating beautiful, comfortable indoor spaces that use creativity and practicality. It is an application-oriented field that needs a lot of creativity and flexibility.

Topics like design principles, color theory, space planning, and lighting are covered in the Interior Design Syllabus . These courses are available at multiple levels in India such as diplomas, UG degrees, and PG degrees and help students to learn with technical skills such as using design software , and professional skills, like client communication and project management .

There are many popular universities that provide courses in Interior Design like CEPT University , NID Ahmedabad , SRM Institute of Science and Technology . Admission to these top colleges is done on the basis of Entrance exams like CUET , UCEED , NID Entrance , NIFT Entrance.

After pursuing the Interior Design course you can become Interior Designer , Researcher, Teacher, Consultant, Product Designer and open the golden door of vast career opportunities in the Design Industry with earnings somewhere between INR 4 LPA to INR 12 LPA.

faqs.question: Are Interior Design courses worth my time and money?
faqs.answer: This is a subjective question, and the answer to this would differ from one person to another, based on individual future plans, interests, and dedication to the field. Generally, the Interior Design courses are the perfect fit for creative souls who enjoy planning and designing and have great taste . From the entire interior planning to furniture selection, interior designers are the go-to people for the clients so that they can enjoy a beautiful and comfortable living space. You can look forward to excellent earning opportunities after completing Interior Designer courses with decent salary packages. Short-term skill-based certificate and Diploma courses in Interior Designing can be worthwhile for students planning to start their professional journey early, are low on budget, and look at it more as a hobby or side income . On the other hand, if you're planning to start a healthy career journey in this field, it is better to go for full-fledged degree courses that focus both on theory classes and practical learning, along with skill development and connection building.

faqs.question: Can I pursue Interior Designing after class 12th?
faqs.answer: A candidate who has cleared their Class 12 from any stream ( Science / Commerce / Arts ), can pursue a Interior Designing course at the graduation level. Most popular colleges allow candidates to participate in their admission process only if they have completed their schooling from a recognised board. Most colleges prefer candidates who have studied Mathematics and Physics as a full-time course or as an additional subject in class 12. For merit-based admissions, students must secure more than 80% in the qualifying exam.

faqs.question: How much time is involved in the Interior Designing admission process?
faqs.answer: The time involved in the Interior Designing admission process differs on the basis of the design institute or college where you're planning to pursue the course. In general, it can easily take at least 2 to 4 months because each college follows their own guidelines for admission to Interior Design courses often including entrance exams, college application forms, results, merit lists, interviews, and portfolio submissions. You can go to the official websites of your preferred Interior Design colleges to have better clarity of their admission and selection criteria.

faqs.question: Can I apply for Masters in Interior Design program without having a B.Des in Interior Design degree?
faqs.answer: Yes, you can surely apply for a Master's in Interior Design if you don't even have a B.Des in Interior Design. Many colleges accept students from different fields as long as they have a relevant bachelor's degree like Architecture, Fine Arts, Design, Civil Engineering, or any 10+2+3 degree. So yes, it is totally possible you don't need a B.Des specifically to apply. Good Luck!

faqs.question: Which technical skills are required to become an Interior Designer?
faqs.answer: Here are some technical skills you will need to be a good Interior Designer: Using 3D Interior Design modelling tools. Precision sketching to know how to communicate your Interior Design ideas. Computer-Aided-Design (CAD). Architectural detailing and building codes.

faqs.question: What is the starting salary of an Interior Designer in India?
faqs.answer: Diverse job opportunities exist in front of Interior Design professionals. They may either choose to work under supervised setup (Design studios and Interior design firms) or work independently. When it comes to Government sector jobs, PWDs, Municipal Corporations and Town Planning Departments are known to hire interior design professionals. They may also become part of Government schemes related to housing and relocation of people. Starting salary depends on a number of different factors. Prominent factors are- profile of the employer, employee skills, aptitude and grades attained by the employee. In the beginning, interior designers may earn INR 3 -4 LPA. The salary package will eventually rise after gaining work experience. If one decides to remain self employed, salary figure will be quite different.

faqs.question: Can I work with big Interior Designers?
faqs.answer: Of course, you can work with a Big Interior Design firm or with a famous Interior Designer once you complete an Interior Designing course . These firms also seek skilled professionals for job roles. You can make a portfolio, get relevant experience or skills in the field, and apply for a full-time job or an internship.

faqs.question: What is Interior Designing all about?

blocks.value: Interior spaces play a huge role in shaping psychological behaviour. Good aesthetical symmetry induces emotional well-being. At the same time, functionality within the four walls matters. In cramped urban environments, it is harder to have a blend of both. A well-planned yet creative interior design achieves this much-needed balance. Interior design is the art of designing spaces that have a mixture of both aesthetic appeal and technical skills . It is the field of creating spaces that appeal to our senses while being practically useful. It refers to innovative and technical solutions for creating a purposeful environment within a house, room or any four-walled space. It can include the choice and placement of paintings, rugs, murals, furniture, wall colour, lighting, sculptures, organic or natural forms , and so on.

faqs.question: What are the main areas of Interior Design?

blocks.value: There are three main areas of interest in Interior Design: H ouse Decoration, Residential Design and Commercial Design . Studies offer knowledge and relevant information on elements and principles of design, architectural design and survey, interior planning, or graphic techniques for interior design. Interior Design helps students develop creative abilities and excellent interpersonal skills. Interior design professionals are generally organised people with a great attention to detail.

blocks.value: Interior Design courses are one of the most exciting and challenging courses students can look out for during their higher studies. Interior Design courses include BDes Interior Design, BSc Interior Design, Diploma in Interior Design, etc. Interior Design courses can be pursued after students complete 10+2. After schooling, candidates who have a knack for creativity, as well as have a scientific approach, can opt for this course. Interior Design courses can be pursued at the PG level too.

To start with, the course is taught in various colleges in India. Some popular colleges for Interior Design courses include Unitedworld Institute of Design , Indian Institute of Arts and Design , Pearl Academy , etc. Admissions can be merit-based or entrance exam based.
Popular Interior Design Courses
The popular Interior Design courses in India include degrees at UG level, PG level, certificate and diploma levels. Following are the most popular Interior Design courses:
BDes Interior Design

BDes in Interior Design is a course of 4 years duration. This course deals with the arts and science of creating functional spaces that are efficient and in line with the trends. This course teaches the students how to balance the creativity, functionality, and efficiency of any space strategically. Candidates who have studied Physics , Chemistry, Biology, and Mathematics as subjects in 10+2 can take this course.
BSc Interior Design

BSc Interior Design course is of 3 years duration and can be pursued after 10+2. This course deals with the science of designing functional space for commercial or personal buildings, apartments or houses. In this course, students are taught about the scientific and logical methods of designing great interior spaces. Candidates who have studied Physics, Chemistry, Biology, and Mathematics as subjects in 10+2 can take this course.
DFP-Banner
MDes Interior Design

Students who have a sense of aesthetics and creativity can upgrade their knowledge with the MDes in Interior Design course. This course is pursued after graduation and is of 2 years duration. This course teaches a higher level of personal creativity with professional skills such as project management. Candidates can find themselves learning the technical and artistic forms of communication.
MSc Interior Design

The MSc in interior ensign course is of 2 years duration. This course deals with the specialisation of Interior Designing concepts. Skills needed for designing, experimenting, and materializing a space are taught in this course. This course can be pursued after graduation.

blocks.value: How to Take Admission in Interior Design Courses?

The Interior Design course is available at 2 levels - UG and PG. Apart from that, certificate and diploma courses are also available, as discussed above. But, how do you take admission in these courses? Let us discuss it below:
Admission to UG Interior Design Courses

Admission to the UG Interior Design course is offered after 10+2. Admission depends on college to college. Some colleges take admission in UG Interior Design courses based on entrance exams (national / institute level), on the other hand, some take admission based on merit in qualifying exams. However, all admissions are subject to fulfilment of the eligibility criteria that includes minimum marks in the qualifying exam, age, nationality, etc.
Admission to PG Interior Design Courses

To take admission in the PG Interior Design courses, candidates have to be a graduate with relevant degrees. There might be a need to qualify in the national / institute level entrance exam in some colleges. Apart from that, required eligibility criteria must be fulfilled like minimum marks in the qualifying exam, age, nationality, etc.
Admission to Certificate / Diploma Interior Design Course

A diploma or certificate course in Interior Design can be pursued after 10+2 or after graduation. These courses are short term courses and require no hard and fast eligibility criteria. In fact certificate courses in Interior Design can be pursued online too. No specific entrance exam is required to take admission in the certificate/diploma courses.
Interior Design Courses Eligibility Criteria

content: Interior design in India has a huge range. More and more individuals are choosing to live in smaller, more compact homes due to shortage of areas, growing population and rising costs of houses. In such a case, interior designers can conserve space while adding a distinctive and seductive touch to the area with their theme-based designs. According to extensive industry research, the market for interior design is expanding quickly. Some of the areas where interior designers can find work are:
Links relevant to Interior Designing Jobs:

tables.Details: Many architectural firms partner with or hire an interior designer who co-ordinates with them in making the most out of the space and providing the perfect kind of interior the client wants. This includes various job roles for a single interior designer or sometimes many designers at the same time depending on the budget and time of the client.

The designing of every retail outlet, be it a small unit or a large mall, needs technical as well as commercial awareness. The growth of retail sectors in recent times has brought with it a growing demand for proper and scientific designing of the retail outlet for which interior designers get amazing opportunities to showcase their work.
Interior Design companies particularly hire interior designers specialised in various sectors to provide to the companies or direct clients as and when then the need arises.

Event management is a booming business nowadays. But what goes behind this is the work of an interior decorator or an exhibition designer who plans the designs and layouts to attract the attention of people.
Production designers are well suited for this field as they tend to know various other things related to this field besides designing which is necessary for the set-designing companies.

Another field where interior designers will always be in demand is the hospitality sector. Every hotel, restaurant, bar or even cruise wants to provide its customers with a unique atmosphere and therefore the designing and creative capabilities of an interior designer come in demand. They are not restricted to just designing dining or meeting places but also theatres, golf courses and cruise facilities.

questions.question_text: Is TDV good for Interior Design? Looking for honest feedback on faculty, studio culture, projects and overall learning experience.

answers.answer_text: I'm studying Interior Design here, and what stands out is that you're in the studio almost all the time. You don't just submit work and forget it — you keep reworking the same design after feedback, which really improves your thinking. Faculty push you a lot, sometimes it feels annoying, but later you realise why. The studio culture is intense near submissions, but very chill otherwise. You learn less from lectures and more from mistakes, discussions, and long studio hours. It's not fancy or easy, but if you stay involved, you genuinely improve.
